subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Is there a way to nasalize a vowel? and to express certain consonants?
msgSnippet: Methinks I m not satisfied with the Ing solution. Spelling it that way, Bon becomes bong boN and if you can t let others know that your/ bon /temps doesn t
messageBody:
Methinks I'm not satisfied with the Ing solution. Spelling it that way, Bon becomes "bong" boN and if you can't let others know that your bon temps doesn't mean "bong" times, you might end up in jail! :-)

There's simply no QS letter for that nazalization. I would probably use an apostrophe + Ing: Bo'ng. I feel the apostrophe gives a warning, like it's common use for glottal stops that the following sound isn't really pronounced, and the Ing gives a great hint of the flavor it gives the preceding vowel. Of course, I know that it's not a purist solution, but we're talking about extending it beyond what it was designed for. Until more letters are created (!) I vote for 'N (apostrophe + Ing) to indicate French and Portuguese nazalized vowels.

Also, I don't find anything either in Quikscript or in Shavian for the
pure nasal as in "bon jour". In "bon" the o is nasalized, thus the n
is not a consonant. The Shavian n stands for the consonant n as in
bonfire.

The fact is that we do use Fremch words in English. "Elan" comes to
mind as an example, but there should obviously be other examples too.
How would one write "elan" in Shavian?
    
I would put an Ing after the vowel.  There is nothing in French it can 
be confused with.
